content.title: Vascular History Taking
content.summary: Systematic vascular history taking is the foundation of vascular assessment. A comprehensive history identifies symptoms, risk factors, functional impairment, and guides subsequent examination and testing priorities.
content.definition: The systematic collection of patient-reported symptoms, medical history, risk factors, and functional status relevant to vascular disease diagnosis and management

claudication.description: Reproducible muscle pain with exertion, relieved by rest
claudication.differential: Distinguish from neurogenic claudication (worse with standing, relieved by sitting)

rest_pain.description: Ischemic pain at rest, typically nocturnal forefoot pain
key_questions: Night pain requiring hanging foot off bed?

tissue_loss.description: Ulceration or gangrene from inadequate perfusion

key_questions: Time of onset? (critical for treatment window)

non_modifiable.sex: Males higher risk, females catch up post-menopause
non_modifiable.family_history: First-degree relatives with premature vascular disease

walking_ability.claudication_distance: Blocks or meters before pain onset

content.statement: Vascular History Taking is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Diagnostics that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Vascular History Taking helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Vascular History Taking include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Vascular History Taking.

definition.@value: Systematic collection of symptoms, risk factors, and functional status for vascular disease evaluation

learning_objectives: Conduct a systematic vascular history for arterial and venous disease
Distinguish claudication types by symptom pattern and location
Identify critical limb ischemia symptoms requiring urgent evaluation
Assess modifiable and non-modifiable cardiovascular risk factors
Recognize red flag symptoms indicating vascular emergencies
clinical_pearls: Calf claudication = femoropopliteal disease; buttock = aortoiliac
True claudication relieved in 2-5 minutes; neurogenic needs sitting
Pack-years of smoking is the strongest predictor of PAD severity
Rest pain requiring foot dependency = critical limb ischemia
Always ask about prior vascular interventions - affects treatment options
